history.content:
After looking at the physics 111A website, I think you will be fine. 

--

As a physics-EECS double who has taken all of the courses in question, I can say that you will definitely be fine with Math 54, Physics 89, and Physics 111A.

You should double-check, but I believe that EE 16A no longer covers the discrete Fourier transform (DFT), which is the only major topic that was in my iteration of 16A that you would not yet have covered. (DFT is of course directly related to the FT that you learned in Physics 89.) You might also find it useful to look up nodal analysis, as a quick refresher on how one can apply linear algebra to circuits in an algorithmic manner.
After looking at the physics 111A website, I think you will be fine.

I'd suggest taking a look through the EE16A problems (both linear and algebra and circuits) to make sure you're comfortable solving them, but most likely you'll be fine.  If you did well/are comfortable with 54 and 111a, at most I'd expect you'd need to do a bit of self study from 16A and then you should be good to go for 16B.

Hi all,

I'ma physics major intending to double in LSCS. I have taken both physics 89 and math 54 to cover linear algebra, and I've just finished physics 111A, which is basically a 10 hrs/wk analog circuit building lab class with a final project. Would you recommend that I skip EE16A, and go for EE16B? Will I need any extra preparation?

This is the physics 111A website for your reference:

http://instrumentationlab.berkeley.edu/labassignments

Thank you.
history.subject: Should I skip EE16A and go for EE16B after taking Physics 111A?
